race.name: Lake Country Gravel
race.tagline: 70 miles of kettle moraine lake-country gravel through Oconomowoc, Wisconsin.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Wisconsin lake country. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Wisconsin event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Lake Country Gravel is a local event in Wisconsinâ€”rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Wisconsin lake country is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Wisconsin gravel race. Worth it for Wisconsin/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Wisconsinâ€”yes, it's good value. If you're travelingâ€”skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Wisconsin races: Chequamegon, Bear 100.

logistics.food: Oconomowoc has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Wisconsin rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Oconomowoc provides reasonable access via Highway 94 from Milwaukee or Madison, with adequate parking and small-town infrastructure. However, without documented race organization details, actual logistics execution remains unverified.

length.explanation: 70 miles hits the sweet spot for serious gravel without crossing into sufferfest territory. It's long enough to separate recreational riders from committed racers, but short enough to avoid the logistical nightmare of ultra-distance events. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Wisconsin lake country features what riders describe as "some of the best crushed gravel trails around" through forest preserves. The terrain offers consistent surfaces rather than technical rock gardens or challenging descents. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 3200 feet over 70 miles averages just 46 feet per mile through Wisconsin's glaciated landscape. The rolling terrain provides gentle undulation but nothing approaching mountain or serious hill country profiles. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 82Â°F and lows of 64Â°F, with a 53% chance of rain on any given day. Wisconsin summer weather delivers everything from perfect 70-degree mornings to humid 90-degree sufferfests with afternoon thunderstorms. The variability keeps things interesting, but humidity and potential weather changes require preparation. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Oconomowoc sits around 900 feet above sea level with zero impact on breathing, pacing, or performance from elevation effects. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds â€” no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Forest preserve gravel trails can be linked together through lake country terrain, providing decent scenery through agricultural areas. It's countryside riding that's safe and predictable rather than wilderness adventure.

prestige.explanation: This race doesn't appear in major gravel databases or cycling community discussions. While the area features quality crushed gravel trails, the event lacks the online footprint and competitive recognition of established gravel races.

race_quality.explanation: Without verifiable race organization details, course marking standards, or participant feedback, execution quality remains unknown. The 70-mile distance suggests ambition, but documentation is lacking.

experience.explanation: Oconomowoc sits in decent lake country terrain, but with no documented aid stations, course features, or participant services, the experience defaults to self-supported ride through rolling farmland.

community.explanation: Wisconsin gravel scenes generally deliver solid Midwestern hospitality and the Oconomowoc area supports other endurance events like triathlons. Small-town Wisconsin knows how to handle cyclists.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 100-200 riders, without published results or presence in competitive cycling databases, the racing field remains unknown. No documented competitive field means minimal depth for serious racers. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Wisconsin pricing typically runs reasonable compared to destination events. The 70-mile distance delivers solid mileage for your money, and Wisconsin events traditionally skip the premium pricing of more prestigious races.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Oconomowoc sits close to Milwaukee and Madison, providing decent lodging options without resort pricing. Wisconsin generally keeps accommodation and food costs reasonable, though weekend rates near lake areas bump up slightly. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Lake Country Gravel gravel race Oconomowoc

videos.title: 9 Essential Tips for Riding your First Gravel Race (avoid my mistakes!)
videos.description:
I took part in my first UCI level gravel event and learnt a few lessons along the way, and also spoke to some pro gravel riders about what advice, tips and wisdom they can share with people doing their first ever gravel race or event. 

Content
00:00 My mistakes and lessons
3:41 Pro advice to riding first gravel event

Recommended products:

Get the new Insta360 X4 here https://store.insta360.com/product/x4?utm_term=INRS1KM
Buy Bikestow Stance stand here https://bit.ly/3LSZQXZ

around in mostly one piece and I

from other people's mistakes than make
them yourself. So before we hear from
the pros, let me share my experience
from riding the GRIC in Scotland at the
weekend and the mistakes I made and the
tips I would share with you based on my
experience. The first one is don't start
too fast. I made the mistake of getting
caught up in the race for the first
corner, the first climb, and going way
harder than I had planned. I'm a I'm a
sucker for getting carried away at the
start of a race. And it was made
especially tough because we weren't able
to warm up before the race. So going
from standill to full gas in a matter of
seconds was very tough on my old body.
So I would recommend a warm up before
the race or event if you can which
wasn't available at the gratic because
we had to line up in our age pens about
45 minutes before the start. So we stood
around for ages with cold legs. So that
made it really tough. So given that cold
start, I would should have gone for a
slightly more relaxed start. But I know
the importance of getting a good start,
not getting held up in traffic in the
sort of pinch points through town and
into the first climb. And my aim was to
get a good start and then provide some
sliding space on the first climb, which
I definitely did slide. I slid a long
way back on that first climb as my my
body was screaming at me, my heart rate
through the roof, and my glutes were
shouting at me very loudly because of
what I was asking from them from a cold

conscious about as well. So I went
higher on the tire pressures to minimize

how much suspension I effectively had.

videos.title: Racing the Sun: 204 Miles Across Michigan | Coast to Coast Gravel 2025
videos.description:
204-mile Michigan coast-to-coast gravel race - my second 200+ mile challenge with a new goal: beat the sunset and finish in under 15 hours 33 minutes.

After conquering my first 200-miler in the Colorado desert, I knew I wanted to test myself again. But this time, I added pressure: finish by 9:33 PM before the sun sets, or face the final miles in the uncomfortable cold and darkness like I did before.

The timing was simple but brutal: 204 miles in 15 hours 33 minutes. No room for long breaks, mechanical issues, or mental lapses. Every mile mattered in this race against time and daylight.

Follow my journey from start to finish as I battle fatigue, doubt, and the relentless Michigan terrain. You'll see the strategy, the mix of emotions, and the moment-by-moment decisions that determined whether I'd cross the finish line in sunlight or shadows.

This wasn't just about completing 200+ miles again - it was about proving I could do it faster, smarter, and under pressure. The lessons learned here fuel my dreams of tackling 300+ mile ultra-endurance events in 2026.

Chapters: 
0:00 Preview & racing the sun challenge
1:27 6am start - racing daylight begins
2:40 100 miles down  - the tough middle
3:27 Manistee National Forest
4:03 Like riding on Tatooine
6:23 Checkpoint #3 - Big M
8:25 Sun in my eyes
9:19 The home stretch and finish

Thanks to the volunteers, LTP and the SAG crew, and the race organizers for an excellent event. 
https://micoasttocoast.com 

Welcome to Striving 5280, where we explore what's possible when you refuse to let age define your limits. What are you striving for?
www.striving5280.com

Other videos
My first 200-miler: https://youtu.be/OQiLmLyBASU?si=vBs756Twf7xsnRfO
The 2025 Triple Bypass ride: https://youtu.be/sxw36g1DrLA?si=F7fZL6rXy_fOeTcS 

#gravelcycling #endurancecycling #cycling50plus #michigangravel #ultraendurance

The Michigan Coast to Coast is a 204
mile race across the lower peninsula.
Starting in all grey on Lake Hiron, it
primarily travels gravel roads through
farmland before snaking through the
off-road vehicle trails of the Manaste
National Forest. It finishes in Lington

videos.title: Lowell Classic Gravel Race - 2025
videos.description:
ðŸ‘‰ Hey! SUBSCRIBE for Race Content ðŸ‘‰ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsr-SU_SAqjrzmu4kXIRfUQ?sub_confirmation=1

Lead group 38 mi  race! 

Final gravel race of the season! Since I locked up 4th place in the overall Michigan Gravel Race Series (MGRS) and couldn't gain enough points to overtake 3rd, I decided to make this my Iceman MTB race prep. The short course, 39 miles, would be closer to my expected Iceman finish time in 2 weeks, so I raced that distance instead of my typical long course 56 mile. I didn't feel the best on the day but I was able to hold onto the front group into the final 20 person sprint. Legs were cooked by then and I made some poor tactical decisions in the end, which left me way back and out of position for the sprint. I was able to salvage 8th place overall, 2nd in my age group. 

Held on October 25,  2025, this was the last race of the gravel season and the Michigan Gravel Race Series. The Lowell gravel race is a classic style gravel race. You race along the banks of the Flat River and through rural Ionia County, MI on approximately 95% unpaved roads. You can choose from either the 56, 39 or 15 mile routes, all are single loops. The race start sand finishes at Fallasburg County Park, Lowell, MI.
